articles.headline: A Ham Radio Weekend for Talking to the Moon
articles.snippet: In a worldwide event, amateur radio operators will talk to each other by bouncing their messages off the craggy face of the moon.
articles.abstract: In a worldwide event, amateur radio operators will talk to each other by bouncing their messages off the craggy face of the moon.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Dogs bay at it. Lovers swoon under it. And some people like to bounce their voices off it.

articles.headline: Et Tu, AARP? Good Guys Cut 401(k)s, Too
articles.snippet: The AARP saving cash by cutting the match to its 401(k) plan is akin to the Teamsters hiring nonunion labor.
articles.abstract: The AARP saving cash by cutting the match to its 401(k) plan is akin to the Teamsters hiring nonunion labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a truly ugly year for just about everyone saving money in a retirement account at work.

articles.headline: Times Co. May Include 2nd Paper in Globe Sale
articles.snippet: A letter to potential buyers said the company intended to make a deal quickly and initial bids were due on July 8.
articles.abstract: A letter to potential buyers said the company intended to make a deal quickly and initial bids were due on July 8.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company hopes to sell a newspaper in central Massachusetts along with The Boston Globe and wants the buyer of the papers to take on $59 million in pension liabilities. It intends to make a deal quite quickly, according to a letter sent to potential bidders.

articles.headline: Rules May Limit Cash for Clunkers Program
articles.snippet: While the U.S. law may help raise demand for new cars, it is more restrictive than a similar law that proved popular in Germany.
articles.abstract: While the U.S. law may help raise demand for new cars, it is more restrictive than a similar law that proved popular in Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  In Europe, hundreds of thousands of car owners have taken advantage of government subsidies to get rid of their old vehicles and trade up to new ones. Car sales in Germany are up about 40 percent from a year ago.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Sara Peters

articles.headline: Chasing Small Fry, S.E.C. Let Madoff Get Away
articles.snippet: It’s hard not to see an ill-fated stock manipulation case as an example of misplaced priorities at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: It’s hard not to see an ill-fated stock manipulation case as an example of misplaced priorities at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three months ago, in a courtroom in Bridgeport, Conn., a 72-year-old former Morgan Stanley broker named Richard A. Kwak was cleared of any involvement in a small-time stock manipulation scheme.

articles.headline: House Passes Bill to Address Threat of Climate Change
articles.snippet: The 219-212 vote marked the first time that either house of Congress has approved a bill aimed at curbing the heat-trapping gases scientists have linked to climate change, and it could lead to sweeping changes in the economy.
articles.abstract: The 219-212 vote marked the first time that either house of Congress has approved a bill aimed at curbing the heat-trapping gases scientists have linked to climate change, and it could lead to sweeping changes in the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The House passed legislation on Friday intended to address global warming and transform the way the nation produces and uses energy.

articles.headline: In Political Storm, Governor’s Wife Is Hurt but Unbowed
articles.snippet: Jenny Sanford, South Carolina’s first lady, said she was “going to be fine. Not only will I survive, I’ll thrive.”
articles.abstract: Jenny Sanford, South Carolina’s first lady, said she was “going to be fine. Not only will I survive, I’ll thrive.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As Jenny Sanford headed off for a boating trip, the day after her husband, Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina, told the world he had been unfaithful, she met the throng of reporters waiting outside her South Carolina vacation home, all inquiring about her emotional condition.

articles.headline: Jackson’s Estate: Piles of Assets, Loads of Debt
articles.snippet: Michael Jackson’s business life was a mass of contradictions, and his finances in recent years were perpetually in tatters.
articles.abstract: Michael Jackson’s business life was a mass of contradictions, and his finances in recent years were perpetually in tatters.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Hollywood reacted with sadness and shock to the death of Michael Jackson, Sony executives in New York were on the phone all night Thursday with advisers to Mr. Jackson trying to understand the financial morass the pop star is leaving behind.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Taliban Losses Are No Sure Gain for Pakistanis
articles.snippet: The Pakistani military has claimed success in the Swat Valley, but the stability may be threatened by the militants’ decision to flee, possibly to return later.
articles.abstract: The Pakistani military has claimed success in the Swat Valley, but the stability may be threatened by the militants’ decision to flee, possibly to return later.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARDAN, Pakistan  For the past month and a half, the Pakistani military has claimed success in retaking the Swat Valley from the Taliban, clawing back its own territory from insurgents who only a short time ago were extending their reach toward the heartland of the country.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Pillow Fights at the Four Seasons
articles.snippet: The owners of Four Seasons hotels want to cut back in bad times, but the company is resisting, to protect the brand.
articles.abstract: The owners of Four Seasons hotels want to cut back in bad times, but the company is resisting, to protect the brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO

articles.headline: Acer’s Everywhere. How Did That Happen?
articles.snippet: In the PC industry’s worst slump ever, a Taiwanese company is taking aim at both Dell and Hewlett-Packard.
articles.abstract: In the PC industry’s worst slump ever, a Taiwanese company is taking aim at both Dell and Hewlett-Packard.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan

articles.headline: U.S. and Russia Differ on a Treaty for Cyberspace
articles.snippet: The Kremlin’s call for an international treaty to protect computer security is a likely topic for discussion during President Obama’s visit to Moscow next week.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin’s call for an international treaty to protect computer security is a likely topic for discussion during President Obama’s visit to Moscow next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and Russia are locked in a fundamental dispute over how to counter the growing threat of cyberwar attacks that could wreak havoc on computer systems and the Internet.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Political Shifts on Gay Rights Lag Behind Culture
articles.snippet: Conflicting signals from the White House on gay issues reflect a broader paradox: as cultural acceptance of homosexuality increases, political divides remain.
articles.abstract: Conflicting signals from the White House on gay issues reflect a broader paradox: as cultural acceptance of homosexuality increases, political divides remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For 15 minutes in the Oval Office the other day, one of President Obama’s top campaign lieutenants, Steve Hildebrand, told the president about the “hurt, anxiety and anger” that he and other gay supporters felt over the slow pace of the White House’s engagement with gay issues.

articles.headline: The Eyeshade Smelled Trouble
articles.snippet: After criticizing Zicam’s maker, an independent research analyst was subpoenaed. And the fight began.
articles.abstract: After criticizing Zicam’s maker, an independent research analyst was subpoenaed. And the fight began.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to corporate America, critics and skeptics are about as welcome as skunks at a pool party. And when companies try to silence dissenters, shareholders are often imperiled.

articles.headline: Honduran President Is Ousted in Coup
articles.snippet: After President José Manuel Zelaya was ousted by the army on Sunday, the Honduran Congress chose Roberto Micheletti to be the new president.
articles.abstract: After President José Manuel Zelaya was ousted by the army on Sunday, the Honduran Congress chose Roberto Micheletti to be the new president.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  President Manuel Zelaya of Honduras was ousted by the army on Sunday, capping months of tensions over his efforts to lift presidential term limits.

articles.headline: Obama Opposes Trade Sanctions in Climate Bill
articles.snippet: President Obama spoke out against a provision in the energy bill that would impose trade penalties on countries that do not accept global-warming pollution limits.
articles.abstract: President Obama spoke out against a provision in the energy bill that would impose trade penalties on countries that do not accept global-warming pollution limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Sunday praised the energy bill passed by the House late last week as an “extraordinary first step,” but he spoke out against a provision that would impose trade penalties on countries that do not accept limits on global warming pollution.

articles.headline: Google Makes a Case That It Isn’t So Big
articles.snippet: Google is on a mission to persuade the world — and federal regulators — that even given its size, it remains vulnerable to competition.
articles.abstract: Google is on a mission to persuade the world — and federal regulators — that even given its size, it remains vulnerable to competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google handles roughly two-thirds of all Internet searches. It owns the largest online video site, YouTube, which is more than 10 times more popular than its nearest competitor. And last year, Google sold nearly $22 billion in advertising, more than any media company in the world.

articles.headline: Exiled by Russia: Casinos and Jobs
articles.snippet: Russia is closing every legal casino this week, throwing hundreds of thousands of people out of work.
articles.abstract: Russia is closing every legal casino this week, throwing hundreds of thousands of people out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  One of the largest mass layoffs in recent Russian history is to occur on Wednesday, and the Kremlin itself is decreeing it, economic crisis or not.

articles.headline: It’s Now Legal to Catch a Raindrop in Colorado
articles.snippet: New laws allow residents to begin rainwater harvesting, a practice that water rights laws once prohibited.
articles.abstract: New laws allow residents to begin rainwater harvesting, a practice that water rights laws once prohibited.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURANGO, Colo.  For the first time since territorial days, rain will be free for the catching here, as more and more thirsty states part ways with one of the most entrenched codes of the West.

articles.headline: Journalism Rules Are Bent in News Coverage From Iran
articles.snippet: News organizations that would reject using cellphone videos or Twitter reports are forced to rely on them as an information source.
articles.abstract: News organizations that would reject using cellphone videos or Twitter reports are forced to rely on them as an information source.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Check the source” may be the first rule of journalism. But in the coverage of the protests in Iran this month, some news organizations have adopted a different stance: publish first, ask questions later. If you still don’t know the answer, ask your readers.

articles.headline: Shell Faces Even More Revamping
articles.snippet: Jeroen van der Veer deftly righted the oil major after an accounting scandal. His successor, Peter Voser, will continue the company’s overhaul.
articles.abstract: Jeroen van der Veer deftly righted the oil major after an accounting scandal. His successor, Peter Voser, will continue the company’s overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jeroen van der Veer took the helm of Royal Dutch Shell five years ago, the company was mired in an accounting scandal involving its reporting of oil and gas reserves, a flap that nearly ended its century-long independence. Mr. van der Veer revamped Shell’s notoriously complex corporate structure, merged its fractious English and Dutch entities, and eventually restored trust with governments, regulators and investors.

articles.headline: Paper Avalanche Buries Plan to Stem Foreclosures
articles.snippet: Agents trying to persuade mortgage companies to lower payments for homeowners are becoming frustrated.
articles.abstract: Agents trying to persuade mortgage companies to lower payments for homeowners are becoming frustrated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Somewhere on earth, there must be a more difficult task than this: persuading American mortgage companies to lower payments for homeowners who can no longer afford their loans. But as Karina Montenegro struggles to accomplish this feat for a troubled borrower, she strains to imagine a more futile pursuit.

articles.headline: Investors Compete for a Piece of the Madoff Pie
articles.snippet: As Bernard L. Madoff prepares to be sentenced on Monday morning, his victims are warring over who should get how much from the agency that insures failed firms.
articles.abstract: As Bernard L. Madoff prepares to be sentenced on Monday morning, his victims are warring over who should get how much from the agency that insures failed firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Helen Davis Chaitman is a victim of Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme. So is Burt Ross.

articles.headline: Oscars Need Less, Not More
articles.snippet: And they say the Oscars are never much of a surprise.
articles.abstract: And they say the Oscars are never much of a surprise.
articles.lead_paragraph: And they say the Oscars are never much of a surprise.

articles.headline: In Jackson’s Death, Black Ambivalence Fades
articles.snippet: Concerns that Michael Jackson was not as proud of his race as his race was of him seem to have diminished.
articles.abstract: Concerns that Michael Jackson was not as proud of his race as his race was of him seem to have diminished.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamie Foxx, the host of the Black Entertainment Television music awards, was unequivocal on Sunday night.

articles.headline: Madoff Is Sentenced to 150 Years for Ponzi Scheme
articles.snippet: A federal judge sentenced Bernard L. Madoff to 150 years in prison for running a huge Ponzi scheme that devastated thousands of investors, calling his crimes “extraordinarily evil.”
articles.abstract: A federal judge sentenced Bernard L. Madoff to 150 years in prison for running a huge Ponzi scheme that devastated thousands of investors, calling his crimes “extraordinarily evil.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A criminal saga that began in December with a string of superlatives  the largest, longest and most widespread Ponzi scheme in history  ended the same way on Monday as Bernard L. Madoff was sentenced to 150 years in prison, the maximum for his crimes.
